name: Volgarr the Viking
description: Return to the Golden Age of arcades with a hardcore action platformer that pulls no punches! Possesses all the hallmarks of true classics like Super Ghouls 'N Ghosts (SNES), Rastan Saga (Arcade), Castlevania (NES) and more with precise controls, high challenge, and meticulous design.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP, Vista, or 7 Processor: 2.0GHz Memory: 1 GB RAM Graphics: 256MB DirectX: Version 7.1 Storage: 200 MB available space

reviews.review_text: Played for 15 minutes before I needed a break playing something easier, like Dark Souls or something.

This is probably the nicest review I will ever write for a game I hate. That's because regardless of how I feel about it, Volgarr exists to do one thing, and that is imitate the old hard-as-balls 16-bit platformers of yore. And it does it really, really, really well.  You play Volgarr the Viking, unsurprisingly, risen from his grave by some totally metal deity to kill a whole bunch of everything. He controls like a slightly less-sticky Castlevania protagonist, with no air control unless you double-jump, certain attacks locking him in place, and being launched backwards (usually into pits) every time he gets hit. He does have a bevy of moves like a downward strike, a roll, and some very useful spears to throw that can also form platforms. It feels just like playing a classic SNES side-scroller, and that extends to the graphics and sounds as well. Pixel blood and bones fly as you hack and slash through the game's many varied levels.  IF you can get to them. The make-or-break issue with Volgarr is how much patience you have for punishingly hard platforming. The game uses a very Ghosts 'n' Goblins system where you find bits of armor to bolt on to yourself that then get knocked off a couple pieces at a time by enemies. Your shield is one of those pieces, and if you lose it, certain traps are going to be all but impassable. This is to say nothing of the many bottomless pits and trap enemies waiting just off screen to knock you into them. All of this would be fine, except that the levels are made up of two quite lengthy sections with only a single checkpoint between them. This means any mistakes you make are punished with redoing the last couple minutes of exacting platforming again. And with no checkpoint before bosses, just learning their patterns or performing less than perfectly can force you to replay 5+ minutes of level you've already had to suffer through.  This to me is just straight-up bad design, evidenced by how few games make use of similarly punishing systems now. It is forgiven only because it was the standard for NES classics such as Castlevania and Mega Man, except that even those games had multiple checkpoints per level. It becomes a question of how much of your time a game is allowed to waste when you make a mistake, because doing the same level opening ten times because you can't quite get a boss's pattern down immediately is very much a waste of time. Modern games like Dark Souls have found elegant solutions to this problem, such as allowing you to accumulate resources across attempts. Volgarr makes no provision for that, forcing the same actions over and over until it (hopefully) becomes muscle memory.  I really did hate Volgarr when I started playing it, but after a little more time with it I came to at least appreciate what it represents. When I was a kid, I had the patience to beat my head against Ninja Gaiden II for weeks and weeks until I could finally finish it. I don't have the time or the inclination for that kind of dedicated memorization anymore, but I can see where there might still be space for it. Volgarr is very much not for everyone and smacks of the kind of game that gets recommended by everyone and played by no one, but if you really, truly are looking for that brick wall NES difficulty curve, look no further.

I enjoy difficult platformers, but having such sparse checkpoints makes the game almost unplayable to me. I don't want to go through the entire level again because I died in two seconds to the boss at the end. Like, I've memorized the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ level, it's not fun anymore.  You can make games with a heavy retro feel while still incorporating modern advancements in game design. There's still a lot to love about this game, but I found it to be 'old school' in both the fun ways and the stupid ways
The day I finish this game will be the day I become a man.  Highly recommended for anybody looking for a challenge in the spirit of Ghosts 'n' Goblins.
Nice simple design. Its basicly the game you wished for 25 years ago. I enjoyed it alot, mostly while watching series on the side.
I love this game.  And like all naughty lovers, it sometimes likes to make love from behind.  But I still love it.
With a rich moveset, brilliantly layered stage design, and an ingenious difficulty structure, any fan of action-platformers who doesn't pick this up is doing themselves a disservice. Buy this now.

With its simple controlls, stylish 16-bit graphics, and tough as nails gameplay, Volgarr the Viking stands out as a spiritual successor to many of the games from the SNES and Genesis age. This game kicks your ♥♥♥ from the get go and presents a wide variety of challenges through out. Each level presents different enemies that all require adjustment of your play-style to combat and when you finally do beat a level it is that much more satisfying. If you are a fan of 2D side scrolling games I highly recommend this game, though I also recommend you have a gamepad and are ready to have your ♥♥♥ handed to you.

Was Dark Souls to easy for you? Do you enjoy finding new and creative ways to die? Do you not like you're current Keyboard or Controller and want an excuse to throw them at a wall?  If you answered Yes to any of these question then this is the game for you! I mean, even if you answered no to them all... Still buy it!

This game... Like a combo of Ghosts'n'Goblins and Zelda 2. It takes elements from both of them, and throws them together into a golden gem. At first I found it frustrating, then infuriating, and now... Now, I find it amazing.  It runs very smoothly (important for a game reliant on precision control). Even though you have a limited number of moves, you will learn how to combo them together, and each move has several uses. Roll to dodge, move faster, or make a small hop down a ledge. Jumping combined with spear-stepping can let you climb a flat wall. Double-jump can become a major attack, and when combined with the spear throw you can take out some stronger enemies in a single combo.  A full run takes anywhere from 30 minutes to just over an hour, depending on how much you die. If you can't sit down and play the full game in one run (or simply get frustrated), you can continue along 'Path C' with the warps, to any world you've previously reached.  If you are easily frustrated, this may not be the game for you. If you're a speedrunner, a completionist, or just like a good challenge, look into Volgarr. It's the type of game we haven't seen in YEARS.
Frikkin awesome....   Frustrating as hell though... totally worth it.
Art and play perfectly reminiscent to the Genesis games of old, with the difficulty cranked so high you'll feel like a helpless child all over again. My personal indie game of the year for 2013.
Highly difficult, but highly addictive experience ! You will ragequit, then come back and eventually win !  A very good and rewarding game, yet frustrating at times.
It took me 3 hours to beat the first level. I haven't had that happen since I was 7.
Hard but fair.

A great side scrolling game with multiple endings that keeps getting harder as you get farther along. Can be annoying at first but the levels stay the same so with time you'll know where all the enemies are laying in wait and know how to deal with them.

A manly game for manly men. I have been playing a lot of small, short, FULL OF FUN games recently, and I'm glad this was one of the games on that list. I haven't played it a ton, but let me tell you -- it's fairly difficult, gorgeous, and is a ♥♥♥♥ing blast to play. When you get through levels in this game, you really feel like you accomplished something, and I love it. Here's to good gaming!

I can apppreciate the work that went to this game, it accomplishes its intend.  However the game is quite a bit too much about memorizing and mapping enemies in each stage, and dying over and over again until you master a strategy (which, is very NES like).  For what is worth I enjoyed playing it and suffering for a couple of levels, but unfortunately for me it started to take too much time to advance (which mean, took me too long to gid gud and advance to the next level) and ended up not being as fun and decided to drop it.  I would recommend to people that enjoy hard 2D games and speed running, but be advised, it will take time, skill and sometimes a bit of luck.
challenging and fun. like that old game ghosts and ghouls? or w/e

I highly recommend this game which is a true ode to the old arcade games. Völgarr is a bloody plateformer with stunning animations and more importantly, extremely accurate controls. Of course, this is a very difficult game, with almost no checkpoints, and you will die a lot before successfully finish a level, and even more to see the real end which requires fulfillment in a single run. For the more competitive gamers, Völgarr also offers speedrun with a built-in stopwatch. Gentlemen, your records!  -----------------------------------------  Je recommande fortement ce jeu qui est une véritable ôde aux vieux jeux d'arcade. Völgarr est un plateformer sanglant doté de superbes animations et, plus important, de contrôles extrêmement précis. Bien sûr, c'est un jeu difficile, avec presque aucun checkpoints, et vous mourrez beaucoup avant de finir un niveau, et plus encore pour voir la vraie fin qui demande de finir le jeu d'une traite. Pour les plus acharnés, Völgarr propose aussi du speedrun avec un chronomètre intégré. Messieurs, à vos records !

This game does 'old school' difficulty to a tee. If you don't like starting the game right from the beginning every time you play, and you don't like few and far between checkpoints, this is not for you. If, however, you enjoy the feeling of accomplishment you get from playing a level over and over, getting a little better at it every time, and eventually beating it without the help of fancy quicksaves or checkpoints, then certainly give it a shot. The play style and mentality needed for this game is very much like what you needed for the original battletoads on the NES. If you liked that, you will probably like this.

just a big warning..............THIS GAME IS BRUTAL!!!!! if you ever played RISKY WOODS then you know what you got yourself into , a horribly brutal game with no regrets in seeing you die over and over again ......... but you always come back for more to show that you learned. if you ever loved RASTAN , RYGAR , RISKY WOODS , then this is your dream come true , just don't break your joypad while playing ;) good graphics , wonderful sounds and for once , damn fine and tight controls , this game is a love letter to any 90s retro gamer who never played a good game since GODS on amiga. i recommend it highly.

A very difficult action-platformer that demands a great deal of patience and memory in order to suceed. It's sort of like Dark Souls, in 2D.  While challenging, it never feels unfair. The game provides a consistant challenge all the way through, with solid movement and combat mechanics.  Doing well rewards Volgarr with powers to do even more well (yes, that's a thing, ask anyone). Do badly however, and the game strips Volgarr of said power.  Recommended to any looking for a challenge.
Wonderfully difficult game. Not for someone who gets frustrated quickly, but get past the difficulty and it is really a good experience.
This game is a very enjoyable game for someone who likes a challenge. If you play casualy or rage easily do not buy this.

A very enjoyable game that I hope won't be forgotten as the press begins to compile their GOTY lists.  It will mostly appeal to retro-gamers, but throwing spears into walls to then use as a climbing platform is fun and clever.
One of the most difficult and fun game I ever seen. This game represents all that make me want to work in game development.  11/10

A marvelous game. Perfect if you fancy a challenge. Also, that feeling you get when you achieve victory is simply amazing. Not only does it tell a cool little story, it also gives 3 unique endings and hours of gameplay. Buy it.  P.S. Stage 7 is beautiful.

Volgarr the Viking is a 2d platform video game.  I am a big fan of this type of games. Animations look great and gives the feel of a retro game and it plays as one. Very simple controls and overall this game picks up pretty easy. Plays best with the controller.  It is unique and yet fun to pick up again. I find it quite unique among all the 2D platform games.  I give it a 6/10 score.

Pros:  - Difficult and challenging game (with very tight controls); - Addictive; - Ok game design; - Good soundtrack; - Approximately 25 hrs of gameplay if you want to complete and beat all the achievements of the game; - Norse mythology references.  Cons:  - A LOT of patience because you will die MANY times before learning how to beat each world (in the end, your efforts will be rewarded. You will be a badass viking!). :p  Totally recommended! MAY ODIN BE WITH YOU!

Now that's some oldschool gameplay, dificulty and art style not by the numbers '8-bit because it is enough', full on 16-bit glory  Tough as nails, but greatly rewarding Path of the valkyrie looks impossible on first sight, but after you have beaten the game for the first time it seems quite feasible  If you are in for the challenge made by hard patterns and perfect controls, this is the game for you

Pros: - Very difficult, but fair. - Great, precise movement controls. - No metagame upgrades - the difficulty depends solely on the skill of the player. - Beautiful 2D graphics. - Addictive. - No plot. - Captures the feel of the 90s platformers very well. - Great for speedrunning. Cons: - No in-air control, takes some time to get used to. - Can be frustrating at times.  The thing to understand about Volgarr is that it's less a true platformer, and more a real-time puzzle masquerading as one. Each level consists of a string of little areas with some platforms, enemies, and sometimes environmental hazards. And in each area there is at least one series of actions, that, one you've found it, will allow you to path unscathed 100% of the time. At first, figuring out how to pass each area requires a lot of trial and error. But as you get used to controls, and learn enemy movement and attack patterns, you'll be able to come up with solutions on the fly. This actually makes the alternative 'hard' path of the game somewhat easier than the 'easy' path, as by the time you attempt to do it, you're much better at the game.

This is a fantastic action-platformer that fans of old SNES-era platformers will appreciate. The level design and pacing of the game are great, the secrets are well hidden, and every level has a simple, challenging, and fun boss battle at the end. The pixel art on display here is vibrant and colorful, and is perfectly matched with some great music that fits the mood of the game. If you're like me and you've been longing for a great game that will remind you of the good ol' SNES days but not make you relive them, then you should pick this game up.
Awesome retro game as hard as Super Ghost and Ghouls. A must platformer for any hardcore player !
Far and away the most accurate Norwegian simulator yet, bar none.
Ball crushingly hard but fair…. It’s not like dark souls where you can just die, in this game if you die it’s your fault. I’ve never once got mad at this game, just myself for how incompetent I was.

Hard does not even begin to do this game justice. Volgarr could give ghosts and goblins a run for its money...yet, for all that, it is still enjoyable. It's a frustrating, difficult action platformer, with sometimes annoying deaths that could have been avoided with a little foresight, but overall, quite enjoyable. It does have different endings and a different final level if players are good enough to earn them and is really quite fun in an arcadey way. I recommend for those who aren't scared away by a challenge.
A good game if your masochistic.

This game needs an extra difficulty option that adds in more checkpoints. My problem is not that it is hard but that most of the time I spent playing it I am redoing parts of the game I have already figured out. The repetition kills this game. If they even doubled the number of checkpoints I would play through it. This game does not need as many checkpoints as Shovel Knight, but it does need to cut down on the repetition. This is left over game design from the old hardcore side scrollers and it made the games take longer to finish. Challenge was what made those games good, bad check points do not add anything.  Fun game but I can't recomend it.

Volgarr is two different games in one.  Played normally, Volgarr feels like a clunky frustration platformer harking back to the old days of Ghouls n Ghosts. Volgarr himself plods along at a decent speed, but is flatly underequipped for most of what the game throws at him. The challenges are simple but Volgarr is simpler. You plod along, hopping about, dying a lot, learning the levels, and generally barely avoiding boredom because nothing in this game is done especially well.  Until...  You find the second game. As you repeat the levels over and over, you start to get a feel for what needs to be done. You'll brush up against that second game a few times before you finally realize what's going on. The levels are actually meticulously designed. If you move quickly, throw spears at the right times, and generally play the game as if you're speedrunning, the levels will come together. Every single stupid thing in the game becomes easily surmountable when you deal with it the second it comes on the screen. Enemies will line up perfectly to be killed with one spear, platforming will go by as quick as Volgarr's lumbering gait takes him...  This is the true Volgarr the Viking. It's not a platformer in the classic since, it's a trial and error speedrunner without the speed. Almost like a rhythm game at times only you can really only find out what the notes are and when by blindly stumbling over them and restarting anew. Since the game's final level can really only be unlocked by beating each level without getting hit and with finding the secret macguffin in each level, this really is what they intended for the game.  It's meticulously designed to foster perfect play while doing next to nothing to teach perfect play. Hell, the game barely teaches you the core mechanics except in one of those passive tutorials that people who watched that one MMX1 video are so fond of.  The problem is... it still doesn't make the game all that good. Any imperfect run just falls back into that first, really boring game (Only now with the knowledge that you are screwed out of anything satisfying knowing what you missed.), and high-end Volgarr play just does not satisfy enough to be worth the trial and error grinding to perfect each level.

Volgarr the Viking aims to be an old-school tough-as-nails platformer. Volgarr is a fellow that looks more like a norse barbarian than a viking to me, his jumps are stiff and you're so badass that enemies take 1-3 hits (bosses not included) to kill. These said monsters keep coming up all the time so you better move since they won't run dry. The gameplay reminds a bit of old NES game Trojan in a not so positive way (oh the slow walking, oh the stifness of my actions).  You can hit, jump, point your sword downwards while jumping, do a sort of a double-jump by slashing in mid-air and throw a javelin that also works as a platform for you. You can't change direction or control the jumping much so better not spam it too much.  Then the straight-up bs part:  Volgarr attempts to be hard. Real hard. IT sure is difficult but the difficulty comes from mistakes you make over and over again while playing the same part until you get it right and move to next nasty room. This TOO is usual, nothing too bad. BUT. Everytime I died I felt that 'was that something I should've guessed?' or 'if the controls were any better this could be easily done'. Both of these could be dismissed as a bad player ranting but I've done my share of hard platformers like Ninja Gaiden, Battletoads, 100% completed Meat Boy and went through Spelunky without serious problems to name a few.  Worst part is that the gameplay feels so clunky that I don't want to get accustomed to it.   Good parts:  -Window closes quite fast when quitting the game.
ARE YOU A BAD ENOUGH VIKING TO KILL THE LIZARD KING? 8/10.

What I liked most in the game, besides the theme, is that the game is well defined, with excellent gameplay. It brings back the games of a time when did not exist such sick combos of today's games. If you're a fan of old school games, you should definitely try. By the way, nice achievements, very honest and fair. Rise again warrior on the wings of the Valkyrie!

Loose all your lives and you get teleported to 'normal mode'. If you die on last 7th level (Yggdrasil) with your last live then it's game over... Not game over but Ending B.. Which for me is still game over...

Basically put, most players won't make it to the 3rd checkpoint. This game is so hard, it isn't even fun. Don't spend your money on this. Less then 75% of players complete the first mission on this game. Let's look at some statistics. Only 24.6% of players have even unlocked the achievement for completing the Lizard King Boss Fight. And only 54% of players have earned the achievement 'The power of gray-skill' which is where you earn the flaming sword. That is the most commonly earned achievement, and only 50% of players have it. That means 50% of people won't even unlock a single achievement on this game, yet alone complete a single level. Achievements are the best example you can use, because they start being tracked once you actually play the game. If you purchase a game and just let it sit in your library, your achievement stats won't be tracked. So that means, once again, that less then 75% of active players will even beat a single level.

I reccommend this game, but  only if you know what you're getting into . This is a game designed in the style of arcade cabinets and the first few generations of home console games. It's full of pattern memorization, precise timing, obscure mechanics you need to work out for yourself, and repetition. I found myself dredging up skills I learned from classic NES games, training muscle memory into my fingers to get past each section. The one major change from games of that era is infinite lives: No longer do you only have 10, or 3, or even just 1 try to learn and beat an area before you have to start over. Instead, it breaks it down into well-paced but brutal sections, and death sends you back to the beginning of the section. (Quitting, however, sends you back to the very beginning, although I'm told there's a warp system).  All in all, I suggest picking this up, if you're prepared to find yourself immersed in a  'Nintendo Hard'  [tvtropes.org]  game, something that's exceedingly rare these days.

Volgarr the Viking is a great throwback to the times of yore when 8-bit platformers were in their golden day. Smooth controls, lots of enemies flooding the screen, good soundtrack and a classic double-jumping mechanism add up to make Volgarr one of if not the greatest late-model 8-bit action platformer to be made as of late. Ignore my run on sentences and purchase Volgarr now in time for a frustratingly fun weekend!
This is the kind of game I'd ask to play anyone whining about how hard is Dark Souls. And once they finish this one, they can try Super Ghouls 'n Ghosts.

That game is really hard but you just can't put the controller down until you figure out how to cross each zones without getting hurt. This game is like a Dark Soul 2d platformer, which is really a good thing. All in all a really solid buy because even if there is not a whole lot of stages, it will take you a while to clear them all!

Simplistic old-school arcade action with a fair amount of depth, Volgarr the Viking is tons of fun to play and very satisfying when you can complete a level. With no checkpoints and no difficulty settings, this game is quite difficult to even beat a level at first, but once you master the system you will feel like a full-fledged viking. With online leaderboards, many secrets hidden throughout the levels, as well as multiple endings, Volgarr will keep you coming back if you can manage its difficulty.

Oh man... Did you game in the 80s? Classic NES such as Ninja Gaiden and Wizards & Warriors? Do you love a game that is unapologetically tough (but not unfair)? Do you remember sinking quarters into Stryder? If the answer is yes, this game is totally for you. No save points, just check points. You die, you start the level over. Get to the boss and die? You start the level over. Quit the game? Start the game from the start. Never unfair or cheap, this game pushes you (much in the same way as Dark Souls but this isn't near the sadist/masochist relationship of that).  I can't recommend this game enough for us in our late 20s to late 30s. This is the stuff we grew up on. A fantastic homage. If you like metal, it's like the Skeletonwitch/Havok/Municpal Waste of video games.  MAYBE some of the youngins will join the club of tough games for toughness sake. And maybe we'll let them in. ;)

This is a breath of fresh air from the modern era of games where the first 2 hours of a game are a tutorial, every enemy has a neon flashing weakpoint, and you're fully capable of hiding everytime you scrape your knee to regain your health. No, none of that ♥♥♥♥ with Völgarr the Viking. This is a throwback to the glory days when games didn't hold your hand. Instead Odin hands you a sword, shield, and spear and sends you on you way with a simple 'Rise, Warrior. Don't ♥♥♥♥ this up.' It's another shining example of how being difficult without resorting to low-blows always results in an extremely rewarding experience.   My one word of caution is that you'll have to play the game in a single playthrough like the old days since there's no save system. With that being said, you could easily pause and leave the game running in the background when you need to take a break. As a gauge of what you're in for, it took me 3 hours 26 minutes and 94 deaths to finish my first playthrough and I'd say I'm good at these kind of games.

From the outset I couldn't help but notice the similarities between this and the arcade classic 'Rastan'. In places, the level design is pretty much a carbon copy. Volgarr however is a significantly different beast. The checkpoint restart system and unique moves set give this game an irresistible one more go replay value. The difficulty level is set just right too. You will die repeateatedly - very repeatedly - but you'll always know it's your own fault, and with a little practice everything is achievable. This is one of the main things that makes Volgarr so enjoyable.  It's nothing special graphically, but this appears to be the intention. The game's obviously going for a retro approach to the graphics, and to be honest it benefits from it. It just wouldn't feel the same with slick, HD visuals.  If you're still not sure, go check it out on YouTube. If it looks like it appeals to you, you'll love it.

I guess if I had to make a comparison, it would be like eating a regular piece of toast with a little butter on it. Not really bad enough to make me spit it out, but it's not delicious enough to make me want a second helping. It's just kinda there. Get it on sale if possible.

This game is ridiculously fun. It's claim as a Nintendo Hard game is completely true; not thinking your way through the game will result in death. Not that death requires you to not think it through, you'll just die less from thinking. Knowing and personalizing the controls is the first step in beating this; being able to have every control down will help a lot, since this game requires you to be able to deftly dodge and strike when needed. The bosses can be very puzzle like, since you need to know when to dodge, strike, or otherwise act.  Volgarr has two attacks: sword and spear. The sword will probably be used most often, but throwing the spear not only gives you a ranged attack, but can also MAKE A PLATFORM TO STAND AND JUMP FROM. That's incredible! And this isn't just a feature, you are required to use this ability to make it through the game. Alive. There are many secret areas that make you think 'I know what to do, but how', as you need to figure out where to throw spears and where to jump onto those spears.  Volgarr, being a viking, is a badass. Enemies, being dangerous, can rip Volgarr's armor off to kill him. You don't have a health bar, so much as armor. You start with your shield, a buckler. THEN you upgrade to a better metal shield. THEN you get a helmet! THEN A FLAMING SWORD! Each hit you endure will take a piece of armor off, until you have no shield and thus cannot block attacks. This makes being hit a punishment, not an inconvenience, which I absolutely love.  Notes: You can try to avoid enemies altogether to stay alive. You can zoom out, making the graphics better and plan ahead easier. You can set the Zoom out to Toggle which will help a LOT. You can try to learn all the controls, I mean ALL, to look badass and flashy while also retaining armor.  Bottom Line is; I love this game and absolutely recommend it's full price. It's hard but very rewarding, in a way that games like Rastan, Dark Souls, older Zelda games, and even Super Mario World portray. If you are easily angered, however, probably don't buy this. You will die a lot before you develop a strategy.

When you finish your first session of Volgarr, one thing becomes abundantly clear : Either you're in love or you've simply wasted your money.  This game is extremely hard but manages to strike that balance between frustration and that wonderful feeling of accomplishment that only comes from punitive, hardcore games. If the level design and enemy behaviors weren't expertly handled I would've stopped playing a long time ago. Fortunately, this game is very precisely and masterfully crafted and I just can't put it down.  There is no way around it, you will have to memorize enemy patterns, attacks and level layouts in order to progress. Getting hit means losing a power-up, just like in Super Mario Bros. While it is possible to keep trudging forward without these power-ups, it makes the game a whole lot trickier  If you manage to get through a level without getting hit, you get more Gold and a chance to play a bonus level. In this way, Volgarr forces you into Speedrunning. If you don't like old-school games where repetition and pattern mastery is obligatory, you will hate Volgarr.  Super Meat boy is the most recent example of this kind of experience; It's a game which is hard but its pacing and level length / instant respawn was crafted to make sure that you'd give it just one more try before heading to bed. Once you cleared a level, it felt abolutely amazing. The same applies to Volgarr.  At first, Volgarr evokes classics Altered Beast and Rastan; in fact, it could be argued that the first level is largely a re-telling of Rastan's first level. As the game progresses, you'll see some Mega Man, elements from Chakan : The forever man and even bits of QuackShot!  This game is obviously targeted at old-school hardcore gamers; if you fit the description, I really don't see how you can not enjoy Volgarr. It is truly a modern classic masterpiece.

This game is clearly a modern updated take on Rastan. That was a game I liked as a kid but never got much into because the game never seemed worth suffering its own difficulty. This game falls into the same category for me. It's got so much good stuff, but the start-over-from-way-back-when-you-die mechanic really died out for me with the Super Nintendo. The notion that fun is replaying a large section over and over again where one hit equates to failure isn't my cup of tea anymore. It also features that other classic mechanic: knock-back-on-hit (if you're lucky, not straight into a pit). So despite the moderately udpated retro graphics, a decent soundtrack, and controls that feature some depth, the game fails to be something I'd recommend in general. If you're looking for an old school feel in a modern package, this may be one of the best offerings in that regards. But for someone who has played hundreds of those games, and is no longer looking for that kind of time wasting or frustration potential, I have to pass. 6/10

This game was made as a love-letter to a very specific sort of gamer and game experience. I come to this title though more as an outsider, someone who played some 90s games but never really went to arcades or spent dozens of hours perfecting the way I finished one specific game level. I came to this game mostly based on a few friend recommendations and some gameplay clips, as a fan of pixel-art and platforming.  The Good: I really admire this game's design focus. After just a few minutes of play it was obvious that the developers had a specific vision for this game and they pursued that vision with dogged determination. Everything that did not directly support their vision was stripped out, leaving a pure experience behind. Read the developer's description of the game and you will find it closely matches what gameplay is actually like (the description is not full of hype but cold hard facts). For me it felt so much like a 90s platformer that when Steam notifications popped up during gameplay it was almost jarring.   The Bad: Because this game is so focused on giving the player a specific experience if you find you don't like that experience the game quickly loses all charm. You progress through levels by memorizing every step of the level, learning when to throw spears off screen to kill enemies you haven't even seen yet and where exactly to stand to avoid attacks that haven't even started yet. There is no room for different play-styles, personal touches, or emergent storytelling of any kind. There is almost no randomness or exploration of any kind, with this game rewarding players who have the memory and finger-precision to do the same thing over and over. As a result the game is as brutish as the titular Viking, and as exacting as his well-sharpened sword. And that's okay because that is what this game is supposed to be. Just make sure that what you want from this game matches what this game is designed to give you, otherwise it will just be a waste of your time and money.  The Verdict: I recommended this game because it does what it is supposed to do, and it does it very well. If what you have read about this game so far is really resonating with you this game will likely be a good buy. But I personally did not enjoy my time with it, mostly because it doesn't match my own gaming tastes. There are a few friends I know though who still love their old platformers, and I might just let them know that this game exists.
